body:
Hello.

My undertanding is that the version command has been designed to be used with binary distributions of go-swagger (as docker images).

The version is prepended at build time by the makefile in charge of preparing the docker image (actually, this generates a link time symbol).

I don't see why it should be an issue to have it set as "dev" when using the source distribution for different purposes [like you suggest, using it in a non-git place such as vendor].

What your report suggests behind the lines [tell me if you disagree with that], is to use git attributes somewhere to encode the version in a source file, rather than resolve it at build time.

This used to be a common practice with svn or other scvs such as CVS. Git strongly discourages the use of it, even though it is technically possible, with great care and caution. 

Further, go-swagger is still in its 0.x release series. It might just not be the right time to enter this debate about whether resolving $Version$ tags in source code is a good thing or not.

Cheers,

Fred

Thanks for your explanation, really appreciated.

I have a requirement of being able to build from source in a reliable and predictable way, so using "dep" helps because I can pin commits on go-swagger dependencies (that are currently floating; so if you build go-swagger 0.12.0 now, you won't get the same binary/features than when it was released).

I downloaded the binary version of 0.12.0 and the git commit reported doesn't match the commit tagged as 0.12.0; plus the floating dependencies, I can't use it because when we hit an issue we don't really know what's going on.

For example, building 0.12.0 recently, out spec didn't work anymore because of this:

https://github.com/go-openapi/spec/commit/5a4a1e94454f878ce1e1fefff23ea10bd5dd5110

So we really need to use "dep" to pin the version of the dependencies.

I think is reasonable to expect the version command to behave correctly when building from source, even if there's no git information available. I understand it's not a priority for the project right now, but I'd love if you considered including it in your roadmap.
that particular issue is fixed now
Update: so now we have removed makefiles, it is clear that the `go version` command is only relevant for docker images and released binary distributions.

issue.title: how to build specific version?
issue.body:
## Problem statement
how to build specific version , i am always on dev version if i clone the source and checkout a specific tag and run go install on it.

## Steps to reproduce

```
m.hertel@mahe-nb in ~/go/src/github.com/go-swagger/go-swagger on master 
 λ go install ./cmd/swagger
m.hertel@mahe-nb in ~/go/src/github.com/go-swagger/go-swagger on master 
 λ swagger version
dev
m.hertel@mahe-nb in ~/go/src/github.com/go-swagger/go-swagger on master 
 λ git co v0.19.0
Checking out files: 100% (4510/4510), done.
Note: checking out 'v0.19.0'.

You are in 'detached HEAD' state. You can look around, make experimental
changes and commit them, and you can discard any commits you make in this
state without impacting any branches by performing another checkout.

If you want to create a new branch to retain commits you create, you may
do so (now or later) by using -b with the checkout command again. Example:

  git checkout -b <new-branch-name>

HEAD is now at 51061fa3 Merge pull request #1907 from e-nikolov/master
m.hertel@mahe-nb in ~/go/src/github.com/go-swagger/go-swagger on tags/delete 
 λ go install ./cmd/swagger 
m.hertel@mahe-nb in ~/go/src/github.com/go-swagger/go-swagger on tags/delete 
 λ swagger version
dev
m.hertel@mahe-nb in ~/go/src/github.com/go-swagger/go-swagger on tags/delete 
 λ git co v0.18.0          
Previous HEAD position was 51061fa3 Merge pull request #1907 from e-nikolov/master
HEAD is now at 6b23bb61 add release notes for v0.18.0
m.hertel@mahe-nb in ~/go/src/github.com/go-swagger/go-swagger on tags/v0.18.0 
 λ go install ./cmd/swagger
m.hertel@mahe-nb in ~/go/src/github.com/go-swagger/go-swagger on tags/v0.18.0 
 λ swagger version         
dev
m.hertel@mahe-nb in ~/go/src/github.com/go-swagger/go-swagger on tags/v0.18.0 
 λ 
```
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/8426566/57063223-cff66f00-6cc2-11e9-9333-a242f1220ae9.png)


## Environment
swagger version: dev
go version: go version `go1.12 linux/amd64`

OS:   
```
lsb_release -a
No LSB modules are available.
Distributor ID:	Ubuntu
Description:	Ubuntu 18.04.2 LTS
Release:	18.04
Codename:	bionic
```

issue.title: swagger version always displays "dev"
issue.body:
## Problem statement

swagger version does not report the actual version installed.
I would expect an option to report the version of the tool installed
and also the version of the openAPI/swagger spec used.

## Steps to reproduce

I downloaded swagger using: 

   go install github.com/go-swagger/go-swagger/cmd/swagger

It reports the version as "dev"

> swagger version
dev

This is okay I think as it the latest version. The project may not be using a workflow where the tip of master branch indicates the latest release.

So I try downloading some specific versions e.g.

   go get github.com/go-swagger/go-swagger/cmd/swagger@0.21

They also report the version as "dev"

## Environment
swagger version: dev 0.21.1
go version: 1.11.5
OS:   linux/amd64

issue.title: Can't easily tell which version of swagger i'm running
issue.body:
## Problem statement

Running `swagger version` always returns `dev`, and this makes it hard to know which one is installed in my system. 

## Steps to reproduce

```
$ go mod init example.com/swaggerversiontest
$ go get github.com/go-swagger/go-swagger/cmd/swagger@v0.25.0
$ swagger version
dev 
```

If I try `@latest` the same is the case, as using a commit hash.

## Environment
swagger version: v0.25.0
go version: 1.15
OS:  Win10

body: @fredbi that looks like a promising technique for us `go get` users. Right now I'm having to manage two projects using different and incompatible releases of the swagger tool, and it would make it easier to know which version is currently in my `$GOPATH/bin`
@ezk84 yeah I'll give it a shot before Christmas.

issue.title: CLI version: added versioning from module support for go get users
issue.body:
CLI version: added versioning from module support for go get users

* go-swagger version is now properly displayed when building from source using go get:

go get -u github.com/go-swagger/go-swagger/cmd/swagger
swagger version
version: v0.25.0
...

* no change for released binary versions
* no change for versions build from source repo (e.g. "dev")

* fixes #1283
* fixes #2454

Signed-off-by: Frederic BIDON <fredbi@yahoo.com>
